name: Small Pleasures Gift Book
description:
This magical little book makes a great gift for anyone drawn to the creative, expressive, joyful side of life.  The colorful cut-paper illustrations and original poem offer a whimsical reminder that the little things that light us up are vital clues to the path we're meant to follow.  

Written and Illustrated by Sara Saltee

7 X 7 in; 40 pp
full color illustrations
Paperback
ISBN 0-9759499-3-4
Walter Shoe Press, 2006

name: "Ode to an Egg"
description:
This shrine to the robin's egg includes four "mini-poems" of two words each.  These little poems, together with the carefully constructed nest, combine to form a visual ode to the magical egg - a form that never fails to enchant and inspire.

The little poems read:
'blue solitude'
'birth jewel'
'fragile companion'
'sublime embrace'

The blue egg in the center is glass, and it is nestled in a small bamboo dish "nest" with bits of burlap, glass, feathers, paper flower and other bits.  The little angel at the lower left is cut from tissue paper and is gazing up at the egg in solemn contemplation.

The shrine measures 10.5"X7"X2".  Hanger is attached.

name: "Two Reasons for Being Happy"
description:
This is a sweet little shrine to the dual nature of feet as agents of our forward movement and the foundation of our rootedness.  Stream of consciousness poems celebrating each of these symbolic dimensions of feet are captured on the outsides of the side panels.

The shrine also works as a playful numbers game - as the viewer searches for the "two reasons" for happiness, the eye travels past 1 bird, three violins, five shiny leaves, four suns, six gilt flowers, etc.  In the process, perhaps the thought "wait a minute, there are WAY more than 2 reasons for happiness!" might pop to mind.

The materials in the shrine include:  Brass feet, London map vines, foil leaves, assorted papers, flowers cut from Japanese fan, violin images from vintage music book, wooden sticks, sushi grass, crackle medium, gold thread, and acrylic paints.

name: "Cherish Imperfect Attempts"
description:
Here's a shrine to an idea that all creators are wise to remember - our imperfect early attempts are crucial for creating the scaffolding upon which our later, better work will be built.

This particular ladder of imperfection incorporates my sister Shannon's failed passport pictures.  You'll see her there with eyes closed on a couple of the rungs.

text fragment:
“cherish imperfect attempts” 
– Stephen Nachmanovich

materials:
Rejected passport photos, mica strips, stamped tin strips, tin slides, red string, sequins, bee charm, handmade paper, foil leaves w/copper paint, slice of children’s book illustration, rabbit image, wooden sticks wrapped in Japanese foil ribbon.
